NOTE: Please print all proper names and places in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: GEORGE H. GERWING

2. Your address: LAKE LENORE

3. Date: February 8th, 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give place or place and country)

PIERZ, MINNESOTA

5. What was your father's name?

HENRY GERWING

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

May 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. No other place.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to say "I was a small child.")

22 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

No opportunity in Minnesota for our farming

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

advertisements by the Catholic Settlement Society

11. Are you planning to buy a farm?

Yes
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Many thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? We traveled with a group of friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railways.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed at a ranch near Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled near Regina.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

On our farm in Minnesota, and working for others. After coming to Saskatchewan, I worked on a ranch and then started my own business in Regina.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

On our first trip we had two wagons, two oxen, two yokes of horses in every vehicle.

The rain was heavy, we feared to wagons very much.

Placed a crafty strand and placed a long pole over the road.

And one more long rope over the family poles for safety.

Waking up during the night was very something turned.

At a corner of the homestead, there was a big tree.

The next day we started for a walk in the field and found our way back.

We walked back, this short trip for the purpose.

We walked back, this short trip for the purpose.

Clothing a line between 2 and 20 feet.

And Moore Valley to Sunday Church 12 miles away.

42. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

This was a wild country in 1909—now there are schools and farms.

Molotov bombs made the telephone more or less useless.

Time electric power, supplying two or three more homes.

Mechanized and powered a lot of household and other grain harvesting equipment which they are unable to sell.
